title: Affect vs Effect – Confusing Words Quiz

items.q: The loud noise did not ___ him much.

meta.explain: Use 'affect' because we need a verb meaning 'to influence'. The sentence is about how the noise influences him, not about a result.

items.q: The movie had a strong emotional ___.

meta.explain: We are naming the result the movie had on people, so we need the noun 'effect', which means result or outcome.
Climate influences your mood, so we use the verb 'affect' for an action, not the noun 'effect'.

items.q: What will be the ___ of this rule?

meta.explain: The sentence asks for the result of the rule, so we need the noun 'effect', not the verb 'affect'.

items.q: The teacher's words did not ___ her attitude.

meta.explain: Her attitude might change or not change. That change is an action, so we use the verb 'affect'.
Side effects are results produced by a medicine. We are naming those results, so we use the noun 'effect'.
Sunlight influences how plants grow, so we need the verb 'affect', meaning 'to influence'.

items.q: We are studying the ___ of pollution.

meta.explain: Scientists study the results of pollution, which are its 'effects'. That makes 'effect' (noun) the right choice.

items.q: The delay will not ___ our schedule.

meta.explain: The delay might change or influence the schedule, and that is an action. Use the verb 'affect'.
Here we are talking about the calming result produced by her smile, so we need the noun 'effect'.
The policy will influence productivity, so we need the verb 'affect', which means 'to influence'.

items.q: Researchers measured the ___ of temperature on growth.

meta.explain: Researchers measure results, not actions. 'Effect' is the noun that means result, so 'the effect of temperature' is correct.
Pollution influences marine life, so we need the verb 'affect', not the noun 'effect'.

items.q: The CEO discussed the ___ of the recession.

meta.explain: The CEO is talking about what the recession caused—its results. Those are 'effects', so we use the noun 'effect'.

items.q: The warning did not ___ his decision.

meta.explain: The warning might influence his decision, so we use the verb 'affect'. 'Effect' as a noun would not fit here.
'Long-term effects' means long-term results. We are naming those results, so the noun 'effect' is correct.
Screen time influences how well you sleep, so we need the action word 'affect' (verb), not 'effect'.
We are naming the positive result of the therapy, so we use the noun 'effect'.
Heat waves influence crop production, so we use the verb 'affect', which shows influence or change.
Side 'effects' are the results caused by a drug. We are naming those results, so 'effect' is the correct noun.

items.q: Climate change will ___ global food availability.

meta.explain: Climate change will influence how much food is available, so we use the verb 'affect' for this action.
'Effects' is the plural noun meaning 'results'. We are talking about several results of the treatment.

items.q: His calm attitude did not ___ negotiations.

meta.explain: His calm attitude did not influence the negotiations, so we choose the verb 'affect'.

items.q: We still don't know the long-term ___.

meta.explain: Long-term 'effects' are long-term results. We need the plural noun 'effects', not the verb form 'affects'.
Economic shifts influence employment trends, so the verb 'affect' is correct.
The measurable thing is the result of the policy. That result is its 'effect', a noun.
Heat changes how fast a reaction happens. That is an influence, so we use the verb 'affect'.
We are talking about the lasting result on viewers, so 'effect' (noun) is correct.
Stress influences how people make decisions, so the action word (verb) 'affect' is needed.

items.q: New evidence may ___ the trial's outcome.

meta.explain: New evidence might influence the trial's outcome, so we use the verb 'affect', not the noun 'effect'.
